newsitem.title: CHILE: Dazed Chileans await news of Peru crash survivors.
newsitem.headline: Dazed Chileans await news of Peru crash survivors.

text.p: Too dazed to talk, relatives of people on board Aeroperu flight 603 waited on Wednesday at Santiago's international airport for news of survivors as the word "canceled" flickered onto information screens.
"I can't, I can't," was all one woman could say as she shuffled out of a lounge where Aeroperu gave what little news it had to relatives.
"They've just kept us here waiting," said Ricardo Canecho, whose son-in-law Victor Chue was on the plane.

Shielded from reporters by a glass wall, few of the 30 or so relatives were crying, but many looked dazed and shocked. A doctor took the blood pressure of a few people who looked on the brink of collapse.
The Boeing 757, carrying 70 people, dropped off the radar and plunged into the Pacific shortly after take-off from Lima en route to Santiago.
Raul Chiappas, general manager for Aeroperu in Miami, said 21 of the passengers had boarded the jet after connecting from an earlier Aeroperu flight from Miami.
There was no sign of any grieving relatives by 9 a.m. (1300 GMT) at the Aeroperu counter at Miami International Airport.
The only information Aeroperu's local Chilean office had was a brief statement read to reporters by its local manager, Jeffrey Stand, saying the plane was "missing." It said nothing of survivors.
It was unknown how many Chileans were on board.

If the death toll is confirmed, it would be the second time this year an air disaster in Peru claimed many Chileans. A Boeing 737 belonging to airline Faucett crashed near Arequipa in March, killing 123 including a Santiago student group and many other Chileans.
